Award.AwardTitle: Gravity Currents and Large-Amplitude Internal Waves
Award.AbstractNarration:
Gravity currents and nonlinear internal waves with trapped cores are common features in the coastal ocean. Propagating gravity currents can generate large-amplitude nonlinear internal waves, while shoaling nonlinear internal waves can develop re-circulating cores of trapped fluid. The project is a collaborative study of the dynamics of gravity currents and nonlinear internal waves with trapped cores, including parallel complementary laboratory experiments. Wave tank experiments will focus on the stages of transition between steady gravity currents and internal wave generation,and theory and experiments for waves with trapped cores. The project will investigate: what types of core circulations are possible, how they depend on the wave generation mechanism, the development of shear instabilities, how long core fluid is trapped, and the implications for long-range mass transport. Experimental results will be compared with high-resolution non-hydrostatic numerical calculations.

The results of this study could lead to substantial insights in coastal ocean circulation, mixing, and near-field river plume behavior. A major emphasis of the experimental and numerical studies is the dissemination of key results to collaborators to improve interpretation of field observations and parameterizations in regional models. As a key unknown in larval dispersal, horizontal transport by trapped cores can be of use to biologists modeling benthic population connectivity. The project will support the Ph.D. thesis work of two graduate graduate students, and involve one or more GFD fellows.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Internal waves, bores and gravity currents are common features in both the ocean and atmospheres. They are responsible of for the transport of water masses, which in turn affects large-scale ocean currents, and biological and chemical processes in the ocean. These buoyancy-driven flow features influence transport by two main pathways: vertically within the water column (through turbulence) and horizontally across continental shelves (through nonlinear advection). The work in this project made significant advances to understand the dynamics of these features and to develop better models of their properties and effects. This is important as these waves, bores and gravity currents are generally too small to be properly resolved in models of coastal regions and the larger ocean circulation, despite their significance.

The major outcomes of this project regarding Intellectual Merit were fivefold: (1) We developed an improved classification and modeling framework for the behavior at a gravity current front typical of energetic river plumes, that predicts nonlinear internal wave generation, turbulent mixing, and energy dissipation (2) We developed an improved model for the propagation of internal bores in stratification of general structure (3) We advanced new theory and experimental results on the behavior of large-amplitude internal solitary waves with trapped cores, (4) We advanced new theory and modeling of internal hydraulic jumps and bores in regions with upstream shear, and (5) We developed a new framework for understanding the stability of internal solitary waves to Kelvin-Helmholtz instabilities that sheds light on internal wave breaking and mixing.

The major outcomes of this project as they relate to Broader Impacts include improved parameterizations that can be incorporated into ocean models of regional circulation. These can be used, for example, in modeling population dynamics of marine species or chemical impacts on coastal waters from river plumes. This grant supported the WHOI GFD Laboratory, an important resources for the Physical Oceanographic community. It has also supported work in the UNC Fluids Lab, which has become an important resource both for scientific research as well as for public outreach, including K-12 educational opportunities.
